localised_text.last_approved_text: Unfailing Aim

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Unfailing Aim

localised_text.last_approved_text: For our people to prosper and our armies to march, it is required that we strengthen our economy and infrastructure for what lies ahead.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: For our people to prosper and our armies to march, it is required that we strengthen our economy and infrastructure for what lies ahead.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Prepare the Economy

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Prepare the Economy

localised_text.last_approved_text: You must engage and overcome those around you, if you are to understand their strategies and methods. Once you have learned their ways, decide whether to emulate or exploit those strategies.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: You must engage and overcome those around you, if you are to understand their strategies and methods. Once you have learned their ways, decide whether to emulate or exploit those strategies.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Enemy's Secrets

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Enemy's Secrets

localised_text.last_approved_text: To grow our nation, you must co-operate with other powers, else your fledgling expansion will end just as soon as it has begun.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: To grow our nation, you must co-operate with other powers, else your fledgling expansion will end just as soon as it has begun.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Keep Your Enemies Closer

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Keep Your Enemies Closer

localised_text.last_approved_text: Now we have established ourselves, we should secure more lands – a firm bedrock from which our empire can burgeon and flourish.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Now we have established ourselves, we should secure more lands – a firm bedrock from which our empire can burgeon and flourish.

localised_text.last_approved_text: We must take our first steps to unite the people of the south. We have feuded with our neighbours for long enough; now is the time to strike and send a message to our enemies.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: We must take our first steps to unite the people of the south. We have feuded with our neighbours for long enough; now is the time to strike and send a message to our enemies.

localised_text.last_approved_text: There are many among the Nanman who call themselves 'king'. True kings rise on the battlefield – do not give others the chance to claim victories destined to be your own.\n\n [[b]]Unification Mandate[[/b]] represents your ability as a conqueror and statesman. Earn permanent faction bonuses through direct subjugation of other Nanman factions – rapidly conquering tribes maximises potential rewards.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: There are many among the Nanman who call themselves 'king'. True kings rise on the battlefield – do not give others the chance to claim victories destined to be your own.\n\n [[b]]Unification Mandate[[/b]] represents your ability as a conqueror and statesman. Earn permanent faction bonuses through direct subjugation of other Nanman factions – rapidly conquering tribes maximises potential rewards.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Ambitious Leader Takes Their First Steps

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Ambitious Leader Takes Their First Steps

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Mighty Shall Rise

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Mighty Shall Rise

localised_text.last_approved_text: Our power continues to grow. We must secure more lands and resources to shore up our position.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Our power continues to grow. We must secure more lands and resources to shore up our position.

localised_text.last_approved_text: To bring peace to your lands, this faction must be brought low. Rally your troops and prepare to face the enemy in honourable combat.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: To bring peace to your lands, this faction must be brought low. Rally your troops and prepare to face the enemy in honourable combat.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Our neighbours now recognise our ambition and will likely stand against us. Choose your targets wisely, unite the strong under your banner, and crush the weak beneath your heel!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Our neighbours now recognise our ambition and will likely stand against us. Choose your targets wisely, unite the strong under your banner, and crush the weak beneath your heel!
Ahuinan

localised_text.last_approved_text: King Duosi

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: King Duosi
Jianning
jiaozhi
Jinhuansanjie

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Duosi, a treacherous coward who cannot be trusted. He must be defeated, when the time is right."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Duosi, a treacherous coward who cannot be trusted. He must be defeated, when the time is right."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Uniting the tribes of Jiaozhi will help me establish my power and imbue a sense of pride in the people!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Uniting the tribes of Jiaozhi will help me establish my power and imbue a sense of pride in the people!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "When those who wish to cause harm to your people tread upon your land, you endeavour the land and those who live upon it to fight back with vengeance."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "When those who wish to cause harm to your people tread upon your land, you endeavour the land and those who live upon it to fight back with vengeance."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Meng Huo commands a formidable presence across all of the Nanman tribes, he must either join us or be destroyed. I have no preference either way."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Meng Huo commands a formidable presence across all of the Nanman tribes, he must either join us or be destroyed. I have no preference either way."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Living on the fringes of the Han himself, Shi Xie looks to find opportunities to expand on his wealth wherever possible. Such a man can never be allowed to rule your people."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Living on the fringes of the Han himself, Shi Xie looks to find opportunities to expand on his wealth wherever possible. Such a man can never be allowed to rule your people."

localised_text.last_approved_text: Lady Zhurong

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Lady Zhurong

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I have already brought one tribe into the fold. Now my sights are set on a larger prey."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I have already brought one tribe into the fold. Now my sights are set on a larger prey."

localised_text.last_approved_text: King Meng Huo

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: King Meng Huo

localised_text.last_approved_text: "My first step must be to subjugate the troublesome tribes of Jianning. We have feuded for a long time, bringing much tumult to the land. This moment – now – is the time to end it!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "My first step must be to subjugate the troublesome tribes of Jianning. We have feuded for a long time, bringing much tumult to the land. This moment – now – is the time to end it!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Surely descended from the fire-god, fierce Lady Zhurong is said to be as great a beauty as she is a capable fighter; a most impressive enemy – the equal of any man who stands against her!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Surely descended from the fire-god, fierce Lady Zhurong is said to be as great a beauty as she is a capable fighter; a most impressive enemy – the equal of any man who stands against her!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I hear of chaos in the capital of the Han. Such things may work to our advantage – we can live free from their meddlesome interference, lest their petty squabbles spill over and they bring their violence to Nanzhong."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I hear of chaos in the capital of the Han. Such things may work to our advantage – we can live free from their meddlesome interference, lest their petty squabbles spill over and they bring their violence to Nanzhong."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "With pride in the culture and ways of the south, I believe that unity among our hitherto disparate tribes can only be for the good of all the Nanman."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "With pride in the culture and ways of the south, I believe that unity among our hitherto disparate tribes can only be for the good of all the Nanman."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Our lands are sprawling, and difficult to defend. My elder brother guards our southern border, allowing me to expand my reach. However, he eschews the old ways and has begun dressing in the manner of the Han court. A most strange development..."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Our lands are sprawling, and difficult to defend. My elder brother guards our southern border, allowing me to expand my reach. However, he eschews the old ways and has begun dressing in the manner of the Han court. A most strange development..."

localised_text.last_approved_text: Meng Jie

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Meng Jie

localised_text.last_approved_text: King Mulu

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: King Mulu

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Duosi has long been a friend and ally to me. I should foster this relationship."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Duosi has long been a friend and ally to me. I should foster this relationship."

localised_text.last_approved_text: King Shamoke

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: King Shamoke

localised_text.last_approved_text: "He seeks to make a name for himself against me? He is a fool."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "He seeks to make a name for himself against me? He is a fool."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I stand at the divide between the North and South. I must expand quickly, or be crushed."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I stand at the divide between the North and South. I must expand quickly, or be crushed."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "His cities swell with refugees from the North, and now he seeks to take my lands from me?!"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "His cities swell with refugees from the North, and now he seeks to take my lands from me?!"

localised_text.last_approved_text: The young emperor has been captured! This is an ill omen for the once-mighty Han empire.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The young emperor has been captured! This is an ill omen for the once-mighty Han empire.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Shi Xie

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Shi Xie

localised_text.last_approved_text: "A cunning official. The lands I own were given to me over Liu Biao. He is bound to covet them."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "A cunning official. The lands I own were given to me over Liu Biao. He is bound to covet them."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The capital is reduced to ash. Dong Zhuo has subsequently attracted the ire of all."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The capital is reduced to ash. Dong Zhuo has subsequently attracted the ire of all."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The most kingly of the Nanman. An honourable man worthy of making dealings with."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The most kingly of the Nanman. An honourable man worthy of making dealings with."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "An enigmatic man. I do not trust him."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "An enigmatic man. I do not trust him."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "An intelligent man. Of all the Nanman, it is he who reminds me most of a Han."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "An intelligent man. Of all the Nanman, it is he who reminds me most of a Han."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Isolated from the troubles in central China, I can build a domain that will carve my name in legend"

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Isolated from the troubles in central China, I can build a domain that will carve my name in legend"

localised_text.last_approved_text: Zhu Fu

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Zhu Fu

localised_text.last_approved_text: I have endured the inaction of too many for too long. With the god of fire as my lodestar, I will bring fury to my enemies and unity to the tribes!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: I have endured the inaction of too many for too long. With the god of fire as my lodestar, I will bring fury to my enemies and unity to the tribes!

localised_text.last_approved_text: "Meng Huo, a strong warrior and worthy leader of the Nanman people. He could become my greatest ally - or my worst enemy..."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "Meng Huo, a strong warrior and worthy leader of the Nanman people. He could become my greatest ally - or my worst enemy..."

localised_text.last_approved_text: The northerners play at their politics, as is their way. Perhaps a stronger presence is required? One who is able to wield both pen and blade with equal strength?

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The northerners play at their politics, as is their way. Perhaps a stronger presence is required? One who is able to wield both pen and blade with equal strength?

localised_text.last_approved_text: Should we conquer enough of this land, our people and culture will surely stand the test of time. We owe it to history to press ever forward.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Should we conquer enough of this land, our people and culture will surely stand the test of time. We owe it to history to press ever forward.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A noble lord, with our best interests at heart, will bring the much-needed security that we seek. Should we follow them, an enduring legacy will be all but assured.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A noble lord, with our best interests at heart, will bring the much-needed security that we seek. Should we follow them, an enduring legacy will be all but assured.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Tag-team Conquest

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Tag-team Conquest

localised_text.last_approved_text: Join the Hunt

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Join the Hunt

localised_text.last_approved_text: Conflict of Interest

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Conflict of Interest

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Bad news! One of your messengers kneels before you, trembling whilst handing over a missive. 

 "My lord! We are the victims of a most deceitful plot. We have no idea who enacted this scheme against us. My apologies!" 

 Shamed by their negligence, the messenger quickly leaves your presence. This embarrassment cannot be ignored; the perpetrator of this deed must be found and punished!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Bad news! One of your messengers kneels before you, trembling whilst handing over a missive. 

 "My lord! We are the victims of a most deceitful plot. We have no idea who enacted this scheme against us. My apologies!" 

 Shamed by their negligence, the messenger quickly leaves your presence. This embarrassment cannot be ignored; the perpetrator of this deed must be found and punished!

localised_text.last_approved_text: A Cunning Scheme

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A Cunning Scheme

localised_text.last_approved_text: With the young emperor under my control, the biggest threat my lands face comes from the north...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: With the young emperor under my control, the biggest threat my lands face comes from the north...

localised_text.last_approved_text: The young emperor is under my control. His ears will be open to my schemes...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The young emperor is under my control. His ears will be open to my schemes...

localised_text.last_approved_text: How fitting that the coward Yuan Shao would ally himself with this rebel, who not so long ago he considered a foe. His desperation is on full display!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: How fitting that the coward Yuan Shao would ally himself with this rebel, who not so long ago he considered a foe. His desperation is on full display!

localised_text.last_approved_text: A traitor to my rule! My prolonged tolerance for this dog and his 'brothers' has finally come to an end.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A traitor to my rule! My prolonged tolerance for this dog and his 'brothers' has finally come to an end.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A clash with this fool was inevitable. His military strength is vast, but his overconfidence in this could be exploited with careful planning...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A clash with this fool was inevitable. His military strength is vast, but his overconfidence in this could be exploited with careful planning...

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Bandit Queen continues to skulk through my lands. Whilst she lacks armies, to underestimate her would be unwise.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Bandit Queen continues to skulk through my lands. Whilst she lacks armies, to underestimate her would be unwise.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The flame of rebellion burns true within us. Cao Cao represents all we stand against!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The flame of rebellion burns true within us. Cao Cao represents all we stand against!

localised_text.last_approved_text: The remnants of the Yellow Turban Rebellion live on through me! How ironic that our survival depends upon an alliance with those we once swore to topple.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The remnants of the Yellow Turban Rebellion live on through me! How ironic that our survival depends upon an alliance with those we once swore to topple.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Another one who once saw our rebellion as a threat, yet who now stands beside us.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Another one who once saw our rebellion as a threat, yet who now stands beside us.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If we must stand with an enemy for the greater good, we will. Make no mistake, however – Yuan Shao is not sympathetic to our cause.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: If we must stand with an enemy for the greater good, we will. Make no mistake, however – Yuan Shao is not sympathetic to our cause.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Meng Huo commands a formidable presence across all of the Nanman tribes – it is clear that the threat he poses is beyond that which I can control.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Meng Huo commands a formidable presence across all of the Nanman tribes – it is clear that the threat he poses is beyond that which I can control.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Shamoke – while I cannot fault his desire to become more, I will not tolerate his aggressive movements into my land.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Shamoke – while I cannot fault his desire to become more, I will not tolerate his aggressive movements into my land.

localised_text.last_approved_text: This manipulating warlord has grown too powerful and in his hubris has not realised the threat I pose to his rule. Soon he will learn that even a hare will bite when it is cornered!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: This manipulating warlord has grown too powerful and in his hubris has not realised the threat I pose to his rule. Soon he will learn that even a hare will bite when it is cornered!

localised_text.last_approved_text: Officially he is an ally of Cao Cao, but perhaps he is but a puppet, as I was?

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Officially he is an ally of Cao Cao, but perhaps he is but a puppet, as I was?

localised_text.last_approved_text: Though it loathes me to stand beside such a rebel, as it stands we share a common cause.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Though it loathes me to stand beside such a rebel, as it stands we share a common cause.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Imperial blood is within me! I am destined for more – my ambition has grown beyond being a mere vassal! First, Cao Cao must fall!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Imperial blood is within me! I am destined for more – my ambition has grown beyond being a mere vassal! First, Cao Cao must fall!

localised_text.last_approved_text: To the north, Yuan Shao is my strongest ally and best chance of escaping the clutches of Cao Cao. For now, that is...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: To the north, Yuan Shao is my strongest ally and best chance of escaping the clutches of Cao Cao. For now, that is...

localised_text.last_approved_text: Petty conflicts around China are endangering our traditions! Order must be maintained!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Petty conflicts around China are endangering our traditions! Order must be maintained!

localised_text.last_approved_text: The cub of 'the Tiger' is nothing but an uncouth and anarchic conqueror.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The cub of 'the Tiger' is nothing but an uncouth and anarchic conqueror.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A maelstrom of chaos and uncertainty stirs to the east, its focal point being this man.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A maelstrom of chaos and uncertainty stirs to the east, its focal point being this man.

localised_text.last_approved_text: "The southern tribes remain a threat to my borders. For now they seem docile, but they are as unpredictable as the wind."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "The southern tribes remain a threat to my borders. For now they seem docile, but they are as unpredictable as the wind."

localised_text.last_approved_text: For the sake of peace, those who seek to oppose it must be removed by any means necessary. An unfortunate reality, but a reality nonetheless.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: For the sake of peace, those who seek to oppose it must be removed by any means necessary. An unfortunate reality, but a reality nonetheless.

localised_text.last_approved_text: My former 'ally' is as untrustworthy as they come. To think we once stood beside one another as friends... What a fool I have been.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: My former 'ally' is as untrustworthy as they come. To think we once stood beside one another as friends... What a fool I have been.

localised_text.last_approved_text: After years of war, my body is beginning to pay the price for such unending conflict.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: After years of war, my body is beginning to pay the price for such unending conflict.

localised_text.last_approved_text: "I've heard tales that when the Earth speaks, this one enacts its will."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "I've heard tales that when the Earth speaks, this one enacts its will."

localised_text.last_approved_text: "This one seems wise, serene, even sage-like at times. While I have no doubt he would offer little resistance, I sense there is something more to his lands..."

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: "This one seems wise, serene, even sage-like at times. While I have no doubt he would offer little resistance, I sense there is something more to his lands..."

localised_text.last_approved_text: An intimidating figure to be sure, but one I shall show no weakness against.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: An intimidating figure to be sure, but one I shall show no weakness against.

localised_text.last_approved_text: One of Cao Cao's hounds roams my lands, raiding and pillaging the northern borders. Chen Deng must pay for such acts!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: One of Cao Cao's hounds roams my lands, raiding and pillaging the northern borders. Chen Deng must pay for such acts!

localised_text.last_approved_text: Hua Xin has had every opportunity to learn his place. Now, he will kneel before my rule or suffer the consequences.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Hua Xin has had every opportunity to learn his place. Now, he will kneel before my rule or suffer the consequences.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Another old fool clinging to the past. I shall help him to his grave.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Another old fool clinging to the past. I shall help him to his grave.

localised_text.last_approved_text: I should have heeded my advisors warnings about this man years ago – I was naive to think he could be kept at bay without military action. I must act now!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: I should have heeded my advisors warnings about this man years ago – I was naive to think he could be kept at bay without military action. I must act now!

localised_text.last_approved_text: To stand beside an enemy of the Han. These are strange times indeed.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: To stand beside an enemy of the Han. These are strange times indeed.

localised_text.last_approved_text: How interesting, Cao Cao's former vassal rises up to bite the hand that feeds him. Whilst he will be a valuable ally now, the past often informs the future...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: How interesting, Cao Cao's former vassal rises up to bite the hand that feeds him. Whilst he will be a valuable ally now, the past often informs the future...

localised_text.last_approved_text: My options are few, to the north my land remains in safe hands. South of the Yellow River is where I will need to advance in the coming years.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A more traditional, unit-centric Total War battle experience.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Focuses on army-level tactics and manoeuvres, where calculated action rather than heroic abandon will win the day.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Focuses on army-level tactics and manoeuvres, where calculated action rather than heroic abandon will win the day.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Unit fatigue plays a more integral role in battle. As such, it is recommended to set the default battle move speed to walk (running may then be toggled via the on-screen button or by double-clicking when issuing move orders).

localised_text.last_approved_text: It is the folly of man that we presume to divine the motives of others too completely. \n\n The eunuchs, employed in myriad positions around the Han, were thought to be the best choice for bureaucratic roles as they cannot be motivated by dynastic desires. This belief allowed them to amass so much power that now they all but control the imperial court - rather than being obsessed with a legacy, the eunuchs are desirous of power for its own sake, and are partly responsible for leading the empire into this turmoil of civil war.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: It is the folly of man that we presume to divine the motives of others too completely. \n\n The eunuchs, employed in myriad positions around the Han, were thought to be the best choice for bureaucratic roles as they cannot be motivated by dynastic desires. This belief allowed them to amass so much power that now they all but control the imperial court - rather than being obsessed with a legacy, the eunuchs are desirous of power for its own sake, and are partly responsible for leading the empire into this turmoil of civil war.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is the folly of man that they presume to divine the motives of others too completely. 

 The Han eunuchs, employed in myriad positions throughout their empire, were given far too much power, using their bureaucratic roles to accrue great, unassailable power. But this is no longer the Han, and the eunuchs will no longer be allowed to amass power unchecked. 

 They now serve the government of the Bandit Queen and her followers, with baleful eyes and tempered blades watching at all times...

localised_text.last_approved_text: There is no denying that only [[i]]Tian[[/i]] can confer the Mandate of Heaven - the right to rule. \n\n And although the power of the emperors has waned in recent generations, with governance executed by chancellors and eunuchs, only the Celestial Son can preside over crucial religious and spiritual ceremonies. Men may lust for power all they wish, but only the emperor can maintain harmony between the realms of heaven, earth and man.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: There is no denying that only [[i]]Tian[[/i]] can confer the Mandate of Heaven - the right to rule. \n\n And although the power of the emperors has waned in recent generations, with governance executed by chancellors and eunuchs, only the Celestial Son can preside over crucial religious and spiritual ceremonies. Men may lust for power all they wish, but only the emperor can maintain harmony between the realms of heaven, earth and man.

localised_text.last_approved_text: It is said that only the [[i]]Tian[[/i]] can confer the Mandate of Heaven - the right to rule. \n\n The power of the Han emperors - those "chosen" by heaven - has been eroded by chancellors and eunuchs. Yet the people defer to celestial whims - only the emperor can preside over crucial ceremonies of state, and thus influences the soul of the realm. Whosoever claims the title, then, controls the very heart of China itself...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Imperial proclamations carry only as much weight as the material they are written on. 

 The Han government has issued countless edicts, demanding reports be filed. Although many are infrequently catalogued, one constant is the register of land of population - published with unfailing regularity, it has become vital to the business of everyday government; taxation and mandatory conscription hinges upon its data. 

 Local officials collect the data before sending it to the central authority, where it is put to use.

localised_text.last_approved_text: With insurrection rising in Han China, the Bureau of Banditry has become one of the state's highest offices. Established in the capital, the bureau is staffed by high-level clerks and secretariat, tasked with the most difficult and egregious of cases. \n\n Working together with the judiciary on pressing matters, the office monitors the arbitration of justice closely, ensuring that the central government ultimately controls the dispensation of punishment, not the commanderies.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: With insurrection rising in Han China, the Bureau of Banditry has become one of the state's highest offices. Established in the capital, the bureau is staffed by high-level clerks and secretariat, tasked with the most difficult and egregious of cases. \n\n Working together with the judiciary on pressing matters, the office monitors the arbitration of justice closely, ensuring that the central government ultimately controls the dispensation of punishment, not the commanderies.

localised_text.last_approved_text: With insurrection an almost-uncontrollable force in China, the creation of local patrols have become one of the most useful institutions. Officialising the practice allows clerks and secretariats to monitor the progress and identify issues as they arise. \n\n Working together with the judiciary on pressing matters, the arbitration of justice is closely monitored, but liberally and forcefully administered.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The sprawling and far-reaching empire is constantly in need of civil servants. 

 A system was long ago established for men to enter into government work by recommendation. At first, wealth was the only measure - insulation against bribery and corruption - yet it was soon required that a candidate be recommended by his commandery. 

 Only those 'filial and incorruptible' individuals, with relevant experience, can be chosen. Yet over time the system has become inevitably infected by the hereditary trappings of nepotism.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
The sprawling and far-reaching empire is constantly in need of civil servants. 

 A system was long ago established for men to enter into government work by recommendation. At first, wealth was the only measure - insulation against bribery and corruption - yet it was soon required that a candidate be recommended by his commandery. 

 Only those 'filial and incorruptible' individuals, with relevant experience, can be chosen. Yet over time the system has become inevitably infected by the hereditary trappings of nepotism.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
China is sprawling, and its governance in constant need of civil servants. 

 The Han established their system of allowing men to enter into government work by recommendation. Initially, wealth was the only measure, but soon the candidates had to be vouched for by the commandery. 

 They sought out the 'filial and incorruptible', but now we shall press those into service that are required, and those opposed will remain silent, or face the Bandit Queen's ire.

 They sought out the 'filial and incorruptible', but now we shall press those into service that are required, and those opposed will remain silent, or face the Bandit Queen's ire.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The baser instinct of man is to acquire power and then, by any means, defend it. 

 The eunuchs, allowed to accrue an irresponsible level of influence, have appointed themselves to administrative positions - influential roles such as 'regional inspector'. Thus, under the guise of streamlining communication, the eunuchs report only to themselves, keeping a constant control of the information flow in the empire. 

 To subvert the will of the emperor is to erode the Mandate of Heaven itself!

 To subvert the will of the emperor is to erode the Mandate of Heaven itself!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The baser instinct of man is to acquire power and then, by any means, defend it. 

 The eunuchs were allowed to accrue an irresponsible level of influence under the Han, appointing more and more of themselves to myriad administrative positions. They reported only to themselves, holding all the keys and guarding all the doors. No longer. 

 The Bandit Queen watches her administrators closely - the eunuchs will now work as clerks under superiors who will watch their every move. Any untoward activity will see them put swiftly to death.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The right man can wield supreme power by simple virtue of his position and his desire. The palace eunuchs - or 'castrates' - are selected for their believed loyalty and pliability. They are installed as palace attendants - a high-ranking administrative position with direct access to the emperor. \n\n Control of interior affairs and the emperor's missives has given the eunuchs unchecked power that they have ardently abused, eventually giving rise to Dong Zhuo, who has recently seized power under the guise of overthrowing their yoke.

 This abuse of power ends under the Bandit Queen and her followers - any eunuch erring from their assigned duties will soon find themselves with much more chopped off...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
For those who commit the worst of all crimes, only the most severe penance awaits. 

 The 'Application of the Five Punishments' began as grievous mutilation of the condemned before death, involving tattooing of the face, removal of the nose, and amputation of the feet. 

 These truly egregious tortures were abolished as the Han grew, replaced with bastinado - foot whipping. However, the sentence is still known, due to its history, as the 'five punishments'; a grim reminder to convicts how lucky they are by comparison.

localised_text.last_approved_text: As an empire grows, so too do its dependencies and agencies. Bureaucracy grows and distends, like a bloated sow, manifesting in multitudes of agencies and commissioners controlling every aspect of the economy. \n\n The commissioners of passage are chiefly concerned with the movement of people and goods across the empire, to facilitate large-scale, government-led endeavours. Establishing farms and colonies on the fringes of Han territory is one, to ensure the border lands became prosperous additions to the empire.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
All things under heaven must be watched, lest man become overzealous. 

 The Han keep a steady hand on nearly every aspect of the empire's production. Notably, the state has established a staggering thirty-four agencies for regulating the iron and salt industries. They all report back to the central government, whose control of these industries allows the state to maintain viability against private merchants. 

 The greed of the opportunistic must be kept in check, lest it overwhelm all else.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Although divinely ordained, the empire cannot survive on heavenly will alone. 

 Taxation sustains government, and tax is a surety in Han China. All citizens must pay a poll tax - paid in cash - based on their profession and means. Farmers also pay a land tax, in the form of a fraction of their harvest. Land and slave-owning citizens are taxed at a much higher rate, whilst merchants pay less. 

 Paying in kind is often a common replacement for cash - silk or floss is often more valuable than any coin...

localised_text.last_approved_text: For every rule, there must be exceptions, just as for every problem there is no single solution. China is broadly divided into commanderies, with each governing itself relatively independently. \n\n However, the urban centres of the empire have much denser populations, and so cities are split into discrete districts, individually administered by a superintendent. These men are powerful indeed, yet still exist below the nine ministers of state; the power of the city is great, but not greater than the power of the empire.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is said that the emperor shall reign with folded arms, his thoughts concealed and his nature implacable. 

 Heaven's chosen is a practitioner of [[i]]Wu-Wei[[/ii]] - to behave without contrivance, 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The 'irksome' daily duties are delegated to subordinates, who are expected to anticipate the emperor's will and enact legislation accordingly. 

 Failure, however, reflects on both the emperor and his staff, so it falls upon them to warn their liege if the path he walks seems unwise.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
It is said that the emperor shall reign with folded arms, his thoughts concealed and his nature implacable. 

 Heaven's chosen is a practitioner of [[i]]Wu-Wei[[/ii]] - to behave without contrivance, 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The 'irksome' daily duties are delegated to subordinates, who are expected to anticipate the emperor's will and enact legislation accordingly. 

 Failure, however, reflects on both the emperor and his staff, so it falls upon them to warn their liege if the path he walks seems unwise.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
It is said that the emperors of the old order were to reign with folded arms, their thoughts concealed and their natures implacable. 

 This is to behave without contrivance - known as [[i]]'Wu-Wei'[[/i]] - 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The emperor's whims were to be anticipated and executed. 

 Now, however, the Bandit Queen and her followers prosecute a more direct style of governance; respect - and fear - shall instil a reverence of the leader, not some celestial gift, and their actions shall be carried out because the alternative is far, far worse...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
It is said that the emperors of the old order were to reign with folded arms, their thoughts concealed and their natures implacable. 

 This is to behave without contrivance - known as [[i]]'Wu-Wei'[[/i]] - 'as the planets revolve around the sun'. The emperor's whims were to be anticipated and executed. 

 Now, however, the Bandit Queen and her followers prosecute a more direct style of governance; respect - and fear - shall instil a reverence of the leader, not some celestial gift, and their actions shall be carried out because the alternative is far, far worse...

localised_text.last_approved_text: Through self-sacrifice, one may find absolution for criminal deeds. To avoid a criminal sentence, a citizen can - if they are able - 'sell' their ranks and titles in exchange for acquittal. \n\n The highest-ranking officials in the Han have been known to do this, on occasion; doing so reduces them entirely to unnamed, untitled Han subjects, but they are at least free men by doing so.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Through self-sacrifice, one may find absolution for criminal deeds. To avoid a criminal sentence, a citizen can - if they are able - 'sell' their ranks and titles in exchange for acquittal. \n\n The highest-ranking officials in the Han have been known to do this, on occasion; doing so reduces them entirely to unnamed, untitled Han subjects, but they are at least free men by doing so.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Self-sacrifice may have rewarded a criminal absolution in the times of the Han, but the times of the Han are ending. For criminals to avoid punishment now, they will buy themselves free from their ruler. \n\n The trappings of the Han mean nothing to Zheng Jiang and her followers - those criminal servants of the old empire may discard their titles and instead offer up complete, unswerving loyalty. Only then will their sentence be commuted - perhaps.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
How best to ensure the legacy of an empire? 

 Coins establish power; they last forever and clearly signify from whence they came. The Han, much like previous dynasties, are most concerned with establishing a single, central currency to cement power over the economy. 

 Yet as time passed and different kings have vied for control, minted currency has reflected this disunity; in the failing light of the Han, warlords attempt to mint their own legitimacy.

How best to ensure a legacy? 

 Coins establish power; they last forever and clearly signify from whence they came. All dynasties are most concerned with establishing a single, central currency to cement power over the economy. 

 Yet as time passed and different would-be rulers have vied for control, minted currency has reflected this disunity; in the failing light of the Han, warlords attempt to mint their own legitimacy.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Heavenly Son, chosen by the [[i]]Tian[[/i]] to rule all under heaven, is granted power and authority by the Mandate of Heaven. The mandate is the natural plan and order of the universe, bestowed upon a just ruler. \n\n Lineage and nobility is irrelevant before the will of heaven, and the mandate can be lost as easily as it is given. Earthquakes, famines and other natural disasters are portents of heaven's displeasure in its chosen, and it is believed the mandate has passed when revolution successfully overthrows the emperor.

Earthquakes, famines and other natural disasters are portents of heaven's displeasure in its chosen, and it is believed the mandate has passed when revolution successfully overthrows the emperor.

localised_text.last_approved_text: China is like a body; every aspect must find harmony and motion to work as a whole. The majority of the empire's citizens live beyond the walls of urban centres, in outlying villages and provinces, which are overseen by local officials. \n\n These officials, however, are stringently disallowed from serving in their native region, and so must move to unfamiliar provinces. In doing so, they are freed of familial biases that may impede their judgement during particularly fractious situations.

localised_text.last_approved_text: China works much like a body; every aspect must find harmony and motion to work as a whole. Now, however, Zheng Jiang and her followers will relocate officials where they are required, based on their loyalty to their new masters...

localised_text.last_approved_text: The word of the emperor carries the power to change the world. The word is imperial desire codified, and the bureaus of the secretariat are responsible for handling all missives from the emperor. \n\n This responsibility confers unintentionally vast power upon the six bureaus, who have had, right up until Dong Zhuo's tyranny, the ability to control the flow of information to and from the emperor, thus gaining power to influence policy. The secretariat thus wields the same effective power as the Three Excellencies themselves.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The word of a ruler carries the power to change the world - the word is power and desire codified, and the ringleaders of the bandit court entourage are responsible for handling all missives to and from their leader. \n\n This responsibility confers unintentionally vast power upon these ringleaders, who are able to control the flow of information to and from their leader. Such power is a heady tonic, and it is not unknown for a power-hungry ringleader to become engorged on their new-found political capital.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Always beware of those who work unseen. Behind every powerful figure is another, shadowed power.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Even one as ruthless as the Bandit Queen needs strong supporters.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The empire spans beyond mortal gaze, past borders and belief. 

 Our land is gifted by the divine, yet there are incendiary elements who will resist all the same. To combat them, the Han assigned each region a commissioner, granted the autonomy to raise armies and prosecute justice in the emperor's name. 

 Yet decentralising the state's power allowed lesser men to amass their own strength, enough to even challenge the legitimacy of the emperor's mandate itself...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
The empire spans beyond mortal gaze, past borders and belief. 

 Our land is gifted by the divine, yet there are incendiary elements who will resist all the same. To combat them, the Han assigned each region a commissioner, granted the autonomy to raise armies and prosecute justice in the emperor's name. 

 Yet decentralising the state's power allowed lesser men to amass their own strength, enough to even challenge the legitimacy of the emperor's mandate itself...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The empire spanned beyond mortal gaze, past borders and belief. 

 They say such boons were gifted by the divine, yet it is not so divinely ruled - there will always be resistance, and insubordination. To combat this, the followers of the Bandit Queen assign to each region an Overseer, granted autonomy to raise armies and prosecute justice in their ruler's name. 

 Whilst effective, this also allows these Overseers to amass their own strength; enough to even challenge the legitimacy of their liege ruler?

localised_text.last_approved_text:
If a man is able to lift a sword and fight, then his empire expects it of him. 

During their two-year mandatory military service, conscripts spend one year training, then another on garrison duty. Before the chaos, this meant a secondment to the imperial capital, stationed as guards or at the whim of the palace commandant. 

 In some cases, however, the Han deploy these fresh troops to the frontline, where they prosecute the military campaigns of the emperor.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
If a man is able to lift a sword and fight, then his empire expects it of him. 

During their two-year mandatory military service, conscripts spend one year training, then another on garrison duty. Before the chaos, this meant a secondment to the imperial capital, stationed as guards or at the whim of the palace commandant. 

 In some cases, however, the Han deploy these fresh troops to the frontline, where they prosecute the military campaigns of the emperor.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The Bandit Queen and her followers need men to fight their wars and defend their lands, and the men required to fight those wars will be drafted, one way or another. 

 Previously, under the Han, able-bodied men were drafted into two-year, mandatory military service, where they spent one year training and another on garrison duty - usually seconded to the imperial capital. 

 The Bandits see no reason to change this working method, adapting it only enough to suit their needs - whilst under the Han this fighting spirit was expected, now it is [[i]]demanded[[/i]].

 The Bandits see no reason to change this working method, adapting it only enough to suit their needs - whilst under the Han this fighting spirit was expected, now it is [[i]]demanded[[/i]].

localised_text.last_approved_text: When battle is done, but the war yet looms, where can the soldier turn to know he is ready? Prudent generals, endeavouring to be leaders of renown to their men, are known to establish military markets in the wake of battle. \n\n These markets allow soldiers and civilians to replenish their stocks of weapons and armour, obtained both from living soldiers and the fallen - both friend and foe alike.

localised_text.last_approved_text: What wars are dreamed of in the capital must be realised in the provinces, and what weapons the capital may envision must be forged closer to the fight. \n\n Rather than fronting the expense of forging, then transporting armour to the frontlines of imperial conflicts, provincial forges can provide a more efficient, local military solution to those all-but ready for battle against the foes of the emperor.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Penance is paid in whatever way the state sees fit. Criminals, damned to a life under the thumb of imperial justice, are often drafted into the military when the need is great; when regular conscripts and volunteers are not enough. \n\n Particularly under the Han, this became a burden of necessity rather than obligation. Most often, these convict drafts end up posted to the north-western outposts, manning the defences against whatever threats lie beyond the borders...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Those who are able to serve, should serve - this is the law of the empire. 

 At the age of twenty-one, the Han conscript all able-bodied men for two years; one for training, and another serving as garrison troops. Even when relinquished from their obligation, these men often join militias in their home regions, reforming during emergencies into a fighting force. 

 It is only at the age of fifty-six that the Han finally relieve these men of any military obligation - peace is a privilege earned only through vigilance.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Those who are able to serve, should serve - this is the law of the empire. 

 At the age of twenty-one, the Han conscript all able-bodied men for two years; one for training, and another serving as garrison troops. Even when relinquished from their obligation, these men often join militias in their home regions, reforming during emergencies into a fighting force. 

 It is only at the age of fifty-six that the Han finally relieve these men of any military obligation - peace is a privilege earned only through vigilance.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Any who are able to serve, should serve - this is the unwritten law of the land. 

 Those who first came to serve the Bandit Queen did so out of loyalty - or perhaps fear yet they served all the same. Whilst the Han conscripted men into military service as a societal obligation, Zheng Jiang and her bandits fought out of necessity. 

 The Han let their soldiers retire after two years, yet the new regime cannot cease. Their armies must stand tall, and numerous, and ready, to answer the constant call to war!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Any who are able to serve, should serve - this is the unwritten law of the land. 

 Those who first came to serve the Bandit Queen did so out of loyalty - or perhaps fear yet they served all the same. Whilst the Han conscripted men into military service as a societal obligation, Zheng Jiang and her bandits fought out of necessity. 

 The Han let their soldiers retire after two years, yet the new regime cannot cease. Their armies must stand tall, and numerous, and ready, to answer the constant call to war!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
As the power of the Han wanes, those who are able to muster their own forces do so. 

 Whilst noblemen are able to swiftly amass a following, there is also a mustering of forces more locally; in regions where the Han's influence is weakest, provincial military forces coalesce around local figures, who then use these forces to defend their lands. 

 They also bring these retainer armies with them when pledging loyalty to another, more powerful leader - those who now stake their claim to China's throne.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
As the power of the Han wanes, those who are able to muster their own forces do so. 

 Whilst noblemen are able to swiftly amass a following, there is also a mustering of forces more locally; in regions where the Han's influence is weakest, provincial military forces coalesce around local figures, who then use these forces to defend their lands. 

 They also bring these retainer armies with them when pledging loyalty to another, more powerful leader - those who now stake their claim to China's throne.

localised_text.last_approved_text: In the vacuum left by the Han, Zheng Jiang rose, and now she and her followers are charged with holding onto the power they have seized. Those who have fought alongside her - those whose loyalty is unwavering and unquestioned - have earned the right to muster troops and lead them into battle. \n\n As the bandits grow in power and territory, there is great need of these ringleaders - men and women who can gather together others willing - or at least ready - to fight, and pressing them towards the front line.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: In the vacuum left by the Han, Zheng Jiang rose, and now she and her followers are charged with holding onto the power they have seized. Those who have fought alongside her - those whose loyalty is unwavering and unquestioned - have earned the right to muster troops and lead them into battle. \n\n As the bandits grow in power and territory, there is great need of these ringleaders - men and women who can gather together others willing - or at least ready - to fight, and pressing them towards the front line.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The regime draws on the zeal and dedication of those who fight for them, as they always have.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The regime draws on the zeal and dedication of those who fight for them, as they always have.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A horse can be a steadfast companion, but without proper equipment, an unreliable friend in battle. Why risk defeat, when the chariot is stronger and more effective? \n\n That was the case until the development of the stirrup, which has allowed horseback warfare to become more dependable and, vitally, powerful. This, combined with the burgeoning trade in horses, makes shock cavalry a viable and, when used correctly, explosive tool in a warlord's arsenal.

localised_text.last_approved_text: When the natural waterways of China are inefficient, new ways must be forged by man - so it has been since the reign of King Fuchai in the Spring and Autumn period. \n\n It has remained a particularly popular idea to dig canals for the transportation of grain from the bounteous southlands to the less fertile north - and the capital; all of China must benefit from the harvest, not just a few.

localised_text.last_approved_text: When the horse became a more reliable tool of warfare, the next question inevitably became "how can they be made even more deadly?" The answer came in the form of 'barding' - armour for horses. \n\n This armour has the double benefit of protecting steeds whilst also increasing their mass and, accordingly, striking power. This increase in weight gives them more raw strength to slam into enemy ranks.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
When there is an urgent need, the empire will call upon you. And if you can, you will answer. 

 So it is with all able-bodied men; even though their compulsory military service is only two years, upon returning home they are expected to serve in militias, ready to reform and serve when the state calls them to battle. 

 During emergencies, those currently serving can have their conscriptions extended, and some may even be recalled - all of the empire must rise to face a looming threat!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
When there is an urgent need, the empire will call upon you. And if you can, you will answer. 

 So it is with all able-bodied men; even though their compulsory military service is only two years, upon returning home they are expected to serve in militias, ready to reform and serve when the state calls them to battle. 

 During emergencies, those currently serving can have their conscriptions extended, and some may even be recalled - all of the empire must rise to face a looming threat!

localised_text.last_approved_text:
If the regime needs you, you will be called. And you will answer. 

 The Han leaned on their system of compulsory military service, but Zheng Jiang and her bandits believe something more… permanent is required. All must be ready to fight, if they are able, and conscription will continue during times of great need until the bandit leaders are satisfied. 

 For when new threats loom - and so many do - they must be faced with as much strength as can be mustered!

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:

 The Han leaned on their system of compulsory military service, but Zheng Jiang and her bandits believe something more… permanent is required. All must be ready to fight, if they are able, and conscription will continue during times of great need until the bandit leaders are satisfied. 

 For when new threats loom - and so many do - they must be faced with as much strength as can be mustered!

localised_text.last_approved_text: China is a land of extremes - mighty peaks gaze down from the heavens, whilst deep ravines peer up from below. Between the troughs and gouges of the earth, mighty rivers criss-cross the country, making perfect natural highways for transportation. \n\n The mighty, vast vessels that convey both military and economic power across China are known as 'Green Dragon' ships. Whosoever controls the rivers, then, could be said to control China itself.

Whosoever controls the rivers, then, could be said to control China itself.

localised_text.last_approved_text: There are always warriors ready to fight if you have the coin to employ them. Men who know nothing but the endless fight eschew the reality of 'normal' living in China, instead seeking gainful employment through their skill at arms. \n\n Known as 'buqu', they are essentially private armies with a hereditary power structure - they rose to prominence during the Han dynasty as the government forewent standing armies in favour of temporary conscription.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: There are always warriors ready to fight if you have the coin to employ them. Men who know nothing but the endless fight eschew the reality of 'normal' living in China, instead seeking gainful employment through their skill at arms. \n\n Known as 'buqu', they are essentially private armies with a hereditary power structure - they rose to prominence during the Han dynasty as the government forewent standing armies in favour of temporary conscription.

localised_text.last_approved_text: There is no end to the supply of warriors willing to fight and die for what they perceive to be 'right'. ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Institutionalised Nepotism

localised_text.last_approved_text: One will always find work as a soldier; there will always be need of warriors.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: One will always find work as a soldier; there will always be need of warriors.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The kin of the loyal and the faithful will always have a place.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The kin of the loyal and the faithful will always have a place.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
There are many ways to curry favour with the emperor, and many ways in which he may repay that service. 

 One such repayment emperors prefer is one of feoffment - the granting of land and titles to relatives, descendants and loyal friends of the ruling family. 

 These gifts are given with the proviso that, in wartime, the emperor can call on them, and know that they will answer.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
There are many ways to curry favour with the emperor, and many ways in which he may repay that service. 

 One such repayment emperors prefer is one of feoffment - the granting of land and titles to relatives, descendants and loyal friends of the ruling family. 

 These gifts are given with the proviso that, in wartime, the emperor can call on them, and know that they will answer.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
There are many who wish to curry favour with the ruler, and many ways in which such favour may be repaid. 

 Those who climb to the very top of the ladder, the rewards bestowed by a grateful ruler could be fine indeed. 

 Under the Han, loyal and noble subjects were granted titles and lands, and this remains a perfectly fine method of repayment. Bandit leaders, as thanks for their service, were given their own lands and commanderies to oversee, establishing their own network of 'nobles' beneath the new regime.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
There are many who wish to curry favour with the ruler, and many ways in which such favour may be repaid. 

 Those who climb to the very top of the ladder, the rewards bestowed by a grateful ruler could be fine indeed. 

 Under the Han, loyal and noble subjects were granted titles and lands, and this remains a perfectly fine method of repayment. Bandit leaders, as thanks for their service, were given their own lands and commanderies to oversee, establishing their own network of 'nobles' beneath the new regime.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The bounties of the faithful are far above the common man.

localised_text.last_approved_text: One of the earliest, and most enduring rules of battle is that position is key. In strategic terms, this is the placement of defences and fortresses. Not only must be a fort be strong and well-manned, but so placed as to make it as difficult for an attacker to overcome. \n\n Upon hills and along the banks of rivers, the earth provides natural barriers to besieging forces, who face the prospect of dramatic losses if they wish to successfully seize the defences.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: One of the earliest, and most enduring rules of battle is that position is key. In strategic terms, this is the placement of defences and fortresses. localised_text.last_approved_text: If an enemy is allowed too much time to prepare, an attacking force will face undue adversity, perhaps even an impossible assault. Confound your foe with 'oblique' approaches, and secure a more decisive victory.

localised_text.last_approved_text: A man may hold vast lands, but no longer is that the total measure of his wealth. The Han government prefer to deal not in holdings but in physical copper currency, paid in exchange for services rendered. \n\n Even emperors, in fact, are known to offer this currency as recompense for those stricken by tragedy, to help pay for the last rites of their lost kin. Legitimacy is conferred, by Heavenly Mandate, in the deeds of the imperial throne.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: A man may hold vast lands, but no longer is that the total measure of his wealth. The Han government prefer to deal not in holdings but in physical copper currency, paid in exchange for services rendered. \n\n Even emperors, in fact, are known to offer this currency as recompense for those stricken by tragedy, to help pay for the last rites of their lost kin. Legitimacy is conferred, by Heavenly Mandate, in the deeds of the imperial throne.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The economy of China is wracked by instability, stemming from the ongoing wars and feuds between warlords. As the new regime assume power, it behoves them to engage in the less dramatic business of stabilising their economy. \n\n A long period of unstable - or entirely absent - official government has left the economy, and myriad currencies, in shambles. By abolishing these illegitimate currencies and taking direct control of industries, Zheng Jiang and her followers intend to control and ease the flailing economy of the realm.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The economy of China is wracked by instability, stemming from the ongoing wars and feuds between warlords. As the new regime assume power, it behoves them to engage in the less dramatic business of stabilising their economy. \n\n A long period of unstable - or entirely absent - official government has left the economy, and myriad currencies, in shambles. By abolishing these illegitimate currencies and taking direct control of industries, Zheng Jiang and her followers intend to control and ease the flailing economy of the realm.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If the government does not work in the interests of its people, then its people will not work in the interests of their government. It is incumbent upon the rulers of the land, then, to see to the needs of the citizens. \n\n They must be defended from war, and be able to travel and to work. Great walls must arise along the borders, stable roads must be built, and farms must never want for water - this is what it is to rule.

Great walls must arise along the borders, stable roads must be built, and farms must never want for water - this is what it is to rule.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If the government does not work in the interests of its people, then it will most certainly work in the interests of its ruler. It is incumbent upon the rulers of the land to see that the economy prospers, and industry prevails, no matters its aim or intent. \n\n The people must be set to work, in the fields and the factories, toiling and producing in the name of Zheng Jiang and her followers. Great walls must arise along the borders, stable roads must be built, and farms must never want for water - this is what it is to be ruled.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If an estate is not kept in balance and harmony, then it is likely to fall into ruin before long. The property magnates of China - the Hao Yu - refer to their guide to maintain a healthy estate. \n\n Their criteria detail the best times to buy, and sell. The savvy Hao Yu may become very wealthy simply by knowing these basic rules; patience, it seems, is a virtue in all things.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The chase, doggedly pursued, eventually gives way to victory, and then the aftermath. The bandits, having grasped at the power they so earnestly desired, must now grapple with the ruling of the land in a new, but still-organised way. \n\n Under the Han, the Hao Yu - property magnates - became fat and wealthy through exploitation of the workers. Now they - like everyone else - will feel the hand of fair and even justice; taxation, unaltered and unavoidable, to every citizen in this new realm.

localised_text.last_approved_text: All things must start from humble beginnings - even the towering walls along the border start with simple, strong foundations. The pottery brick, forged in the fires of the lóng yáo since the times before the Han, gives form and strength to many Chinese endeavours. \n\n The struggling farmers in the fields find great comfort in brick-lined wells; they are built to stand the tests of time, and easier to construct, facilitating the needs of the farmer. In many ways they are the foundation that holds China aloft.

localised_text.last_approved_text: It is the role of the criminal to either die, or to serve. localised_text.last_approved_text: It is the will of those who rule to fix China as they see fit. Infrastructure requires bold strokes, not to mention a compliant workforce. localised_text.last_approved_text:
Even those who are not pushed into service as justice for crimes are expected to serve when required. 

 Corvée labour requires regular citizens - farmers, artisans, craftsmen - to provide a month of each year in service to the state, wherever and however the state demands, and entirely free of payment. 

 Though the state may grow through such means, the people do not look kindly upon an exploitative leader.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Those who wish to rule must do so with ever-watchful eyes, and for those wishing to sell their wares within the city walls, a strict adherence to the word of the shih-chang is vital; from the central watchtower, they observe the day's trading with a keen eye. \n\n And down amongst the merchants, deputies regulate the day to day activity, ensuring harmony and balance is struck between the desire for profit, and imperial authority.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Even during hardships, if one can not take even small pleasures then theirs is a life out of balance. 

 The Office of Arts & Crafts endures, for even when the people are displeased at state control of industry, the craftsmen and artisans of China are rightly revered. Items of wood, lacquer and jade remain highly desirable, and the artisans themselves enjoy a healthy state income. 

 This opulence is balance; a measure against the weight of dark times.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Even during hardships, if one can not take even small pleasures then theirs is a life out of balance. 

 The Office of Arts & Crafts endures, for even when the people are displeased at state control of industry, the craftsmen and artisans of China are rightly revered. Items of wood, lacquer and jade remain highly desirable, and the artisans themselves enjoy a healthy state income. 

 This opulence is balance; a measure against the weight of dark times.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Every nation, even ones born from war and sheathed in blood, has need of talented men and women to craft, to produce, and to sustain the realm. The old Han administrators established offices to revere and incentivise those who would ply their trade in the name of the empire. \n\n Now Zheng Jiang and her new government must use the remnants of these institutions to compel the tradesfolk of this new nation to work for them, too.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
There are many ways one might work for their country - with their sword, with their labour, or with their coin. 

 As copper coinage becomes ever more the primary currency of China, the Han see opportunity for profit. Particularly, the commutation of servile obligations into tax; those who owe one month per year in state labour could find this service waived - for a fee. 

 The scales of justice and obligation are tipped by their weight in copper...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
One may fight for their country by many means - with their sword, their labour, or even with their coin.

 Zheng Jiang and her government do not feel as strongly about this requirement; if, of course, you are willing to pay the administration for the inconvenience...

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Men will always come together in pursuit of a common purpose: wealth.

When the shih-chang organises merchants according to their wares, it is only natural that they will band together into associations - 'hang' - to co-operate in the name of mutual profit. 

When a more basic compassion does not motivate them, merchants' lust for riches will drive them to unity.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
Men will always come together in pursuit of a common purpose: wealth.

When the shih-chang organises merchants according to their wares, it is only natural that they will band together into associations - 'hang' - to co-operate in the name of mutual profit. 

When a more basic compassion does not motivate them, merchants' lust for riches will drive them to unity.

localised_text.last_approved_text: The Han allowed merchants and entrepreneurs to run all-but free, extorting both the government and the people. This was the Han's weakness, and one that Zheng Jiang and her new administration are keen to avoid. \n\n All the same, the bandit rulers nevertheless recognise the need for merchants, but endeavour to keep a tighter control on the hang - trade associations - so that merchants may still profit, but not free of tax - ultimately, it is the state who must benefit the most.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: The Han allowed merchants and entrepreneurs to run all-but free, extorting both the government and the people. This was the Han's weakness, and one that Zheng Jiang and her new administration are keen to avoid. \n\n All the same, the bandit rulers nevertheless recognise the need for merchants, but endeavour to keep a tighter control on the hang - trade associations - so that merchants may still profit, but not free of tax - ultimately, it is the state who must benefit the most.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Citizens must do what is requested of them by their rulers. Whether they must wage war or toil the earth, the burden of danger is so often placed upon them. \n\n In mines dug deep below the ground, in search of precious salt, workers disturb noxious fumes and toxic gases that have lay untouched for years. Without filtration, the miners succumb to the fumes and meet a tragic end.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Greed and opportunity are a potent tonic, and man will always resort to his baser instincts, given the opportunity. The Han administrators have seen fit to release their grip on the economy, allowing enterprising private magnates - the Hao Yu - to exploit the markets for profit. \n\n It is a cruel justice, then, that the Han have been forced to buy vast stocks of horses for their war efforts at exorbitant costs. The folly of the ruling class is balanced by the savvy of the common man.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Greed and opportunity are a potent tonic, and man will always resort to his baser instincts, given the opportunity. The Han administrators have seen fit to release their grip on the economy, allowing enterprising private magnates - the Hao Yu - to exploit the markets for profit. \n\n It is a cruel justice, then, that the Han have been forced to buy vast stocks of horses for their war efforts at exorbitant costs. The folly of the ruling class is balanced by the savvy of the common man.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The Han, in their arrogance, were exploited by magnates; forced to buy back their own resources - like horses for cavalry - from those canny merchants who saw the opportunity for profit. 

 Whilst the bandits cannot - unfortunately - do away with all these thieving entrepreneurs, their power and influence can be curtailed. They will become a rarer breed of citizen, forced to live by new rules that benefit the government, or face extinction. 

 The folly of the Han will not be repeated again.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:

 Whilst the bandits cannot - unfortunately - do away with all these thieving entrepreneurs, their power and influence can be curtailed. They will become a rarer breed of citizen, forced to live by new rules that benefit the government, or face extinction. 

 The folly of the Han will not be repeated again.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
The earth provides plenty for the resourceful. 

 The process of Hangtu - 'rammed earth' - was used long before the Han, and still endures. A damp mixture of earthen materials - chalk, lime, gravel, earth - is packed between a temporary frame. It is so densely packed that, when the frame is removed, the mixture hardens and stands independently, with surprising durability. 

 All across the land, structures rise and endure on foundations of Hangtu - even sections of the Great Wall itself are built from such methods.

localised_text.last_approved_text: If it can be dreamed, then in China it can be made. Since the time of Wu, smiths were creating blast furnaces of staggering temperatures; so much so that by the time of Han such endeavours were a state monopoly. \n\n Stalwart metallurgists could even blend different types of alloys together, creating something stronger than both. Texts speak of the blade of Liu Bang - the first Han emperor - "harmonising the hard and the soft" when made; perhaps he too wielded a blade of such finesse...

localised_text.last_approved_text: Balance in all things, or else chaos. The power of the government must be balanced by the private citizen, and likewise the aspirations of the citizen must be checked by government control. \n\n The private entrepreneur would levy the peasants to aid in their endeavours, drawing them away from the agricultural toil so vital to China. By leveraging the slave population, the state can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the state.

ui_text_replacements.localised_text: Balance in all things, or else chaos. The power of the government must be balanced by the private citizen, and likewise the aspirations of the citizen must be checked by government control. \n\n The private entrepreneur would levy the peasants to aid in their endeavours, drawing them away from the agricultural toil so vital to China. By leveraging the slave population, the state can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the state.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Balance in all things, or else chaos. The power of the government has, in the past, been balanced by the private citizen, but now the aspirations of the citizen must be more closely checked by government control. 

 The private entrepreneur would levy the peasants to aid in their endeavours, drawing them away from the agricultural toil so vital to China. 

 By leveraging the slave population, the new government can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the ever-watchful administrators.

 By leveraging the slave population, the new government can create effective monopolies of industries - the resourcefulness of the entrepreneur is harmonised by the brute force of the ever-watchful administrators.

localised_text.last_approved_text: Whatever laws the state enforces to restrict the merchant class, enterprising men will find ways around them. Han law prohibits the merchant class from, amongst other things, having any sway in government affairs, yet their power and influence is nevertheless felt. \n\n Mercantile envoys often strike out beyond the borders along the Silk Road with Chinese goods, returning with exotic items that delight the aristocracy and make friends of those in power - there are always ways and means of making yourself heard.

localised_text.last_approved_text:
Not everyone can be chosen for an academic life, but those who are have a duty to learn. 

 Private tutoring is handled by those with expertise in the matters and bureaucratic processes of state. At first, this education was small in scale - almost intimate - but over time the classes have bloated from groups of approximately ten to number in the thousands. 

 Increased bureaucracy has a cost measured in weeks, months and years...

ui_text_replacements.localised_text:
